title: 106_s2412
content:
The "National Transportation Safety Board Amendments Act of 2000" is the short title of this Act. It includes definitions related to accidents in transportation and pipelines. The Act also grants authority to enter into agreements. The Act grants authority to negotiate agreements with individuals, private entities, and government agencies for facilities and services related to accident investigation. It also specifies the requirement for entities to provide consideration for the costs incurred by the Board. Additionally, it addresses the deposit of amounts received as offsetting collections by the Board. The Board shall maintain annual records of collections received under paragraph (1)(I) of this subsection. Section 1114(a) is amended to deposit amounts received under paragraph (1) into the Treasury as offsetting collections. Section 1115(d) is amended to refer to the Board instead of the 'National Transportation Safety Board, Salaries and Expenses'. SEC. 4. OVERTIME PAY. Section 1113 is amended to allow the Board to establish an overtime hourly rate of pay for employees with basic pay equal to or exceeding the minimum rate of basic pay for GS-10. This rate is one and one-half times the hourly rate of basic pay for work related to accident investigations. The Board may not pay overtime exceeding 15 percent of an employee's annual basic pay rate. Overtime payments in a fiscal year cannot exceed 1.5 percent of the amount appropriated. Basic pay includes locality-based comparability payments and special rates. The Board must submit an annual report by January 31, 2002. The Board must report annually to Congress on overtime payments exceeding 15 percent of an employee's basic pay rate and the number of employees affected by the limit. SEC. 5. RECORDERS. SEC. 5. RECORDERS.

(a) Cockpit Video Recordings.--Section 1114(c) is amended to include cockpit voice or video recorder recordings and transcripts, as well as any written depiction of visual information.

(b) Surface Vehicle Recordings and Transcripts.--Section 1114 is further amended to protect the confidentiality of surface vehicle voice or video recorder recordings and transcripts of oral communications. The Board will make public relevant parts of recorder recordings or transcripts related to accidents investigated, either at a public hearing or when other factual reports are made public. This does not prevent the Board from using information to make safety recommendations. The Board can refer to voice or video recorder information for safety recommendations. Section 1114(a) is amended to include sections (d) and (f). Section 1154 is amended for the discovery and use of cockpit and surface vehicle recordings and transcripts. The amendment includes defining terms like 'recorder' and 'transcript' in subsection (a). The chapter analysis for chapter 11 is updated to include the discovery and use of cockpit and surface vehicle recordings and transcripts under section 1154. SEC. 6. PRIORITY OF INVESTIGATIONS. SEC. 6 amends Section 1131(a)(2) to prioritize investigations based on criminal acts. If the Attorney General determines an intentional criminal act caused an accident, the Board must relinquish investigative priority to the FBI. This does not affect the Board's authority to continue the investigation. The Board must preserve evidence of intentional criminal acts in accidents being investigated. The National Transportation Safety Board and the FBI will revise their 1977 agreement within a year to reflect these changes. SEC. 7 amends Section 1131(d) by updating the references. SEC. 8 requires the National Transportation Safety Board and the United States Coast Guard to revise their Memorandum of Understanding for major marine accidents within a year. SEC. 9 addresses travel budgets. SEC. 9 addresses travel budgets for Board members, requiring the Chairman to establish annual fiscal year budgets for non-accident-related travel expenditures, approved by the Board and reported to relevant committees. The report must detail foreign and domestic travel expenses for each member. SEC. 10 introduces the Chief Financial Officer role within the Board, responsible for financial management, budget execution, property control, and reviewing fees. SEC. 11 focuses on improving audit procedures. SEC. 11 mandates the National Transportation Safety Board to enhance internal audit controls for financial programs based on private sector audit firm recommendations. This includes addressing asset management systems like accounting, debt collection, travel, and property management. The Inspector General of the Department of Transportation has authority to review financial management, property management, and business operations of the National Transportation Safety Board to ensure compliance with Federal laws. Duties include informing the Chairman and Congress of issues, issuing recommendations, and reporting progress to Congress periodically. The Inspector General has authority to review and address problems within the National Transportation Safety Board. The Inspector General may exercise authorities granted under the Inspector General Act of 1978 and shall be reimbursed for associated costs. A conforming amendment adds authority of the Inspector General to the subchapter analysis. Authorization of appropriations for the National Transportation Safety Board is amended, with $57,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $65,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, and $72,000,000 for fiscal year 2002. An emergency fund of $2,000,000 is allocated for accident investigations. Amounts expended annually from the fund can be appropriated back to the emergency fund. SEC. 14. CREDITING OF LAW ENFORCEMENT FLIGHT TIME.

The Secretary of Transportation will consider time operating a public aircraft in law enforcement activities when determining aeronautical experience requirements for an airman certificate or rating under section 44703 of title 49, United States Code.

SEC. 15. TECHNICAL CORRECTION. SEC. 16. CONFIRMATION OF INTERIM FINAL RULE ISSUANCE UNDER SECTION 45301. The Department of Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration, published an interim final rule on Fees for FAA Services for Certain Flights in accordance with section 45301(b)(2) of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 17. AERONAUTICAL CHARTING. Section 44721 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to adjust prices of products created under subsection (d) to match those of comparable products produced by a department of the United States Government as of September 30, 2000. Amounts received for products and services under this section will be credited to the Federal Aviation Administration's account. The amendments made by subsection (a) take effect on October 1, 2000, transferring funds to the Federal Aviation Administration for products or services.
